preface.p: Intermediate Algebra: Functions and Graphs was written to incorporate the benefits of technology and the philosophy of the reform movement into algebra for college students. It continues the emphasis on modeling, problem solving, and graphing established in Introductory Algebra.

paragraphs.title: Modeling
paragraphs.p: The ability to model problems or phenomena by algebraic expressions and equations is the ultimate goal of any algebra course. We motivate the skills and techniques of algebra by placing them in the context of simple applications. Each chapter begins with an interactive Investigation that gives students an opportunity to explore open-ended modeling problems. These Investigations can be used in class as guided explorations or as projects for small groups. They are designed to show students how the mathematical techniques they are learning can be applied to study and understand new situations.

paragraphs.title: Functions
paragraphs.p: The fundamental concept underlying calculus and related disciplines is the notion of function. While the formal study of functions is usually the content of precalculus, it is not too early to begin building an intuitive understanding of functional relationships in the preceding algebra courses. These ideas are useful not only in calculus but in practically any field students may pursue. We begin working with functions in Chapter 1, "Linear Models." Chapter 2 considers applications of linear models, and Chapters 3 and 4 study quadratic models. Formal function notation and terminology appear in Chapter 5, after students have had an opportunity to absorb the meaning behind the notation.

In our work with functions and modeling we employ the "Rule of Four," that all problems should be considered using algebraic, numerical, graphical, and verbal methods. It is the connections between these approaches that we have endeavored to establish in this course. At this level it is crucial that students learn to write an algebraic expression from a verbal description, recognize trends in a table of data, and extract and interpret information from the graph of a function.

paragraphs.title: Graphs
paragraphs.p: No tool for conveying information about a system is more powerful than a graph. Yet many students have trouble progressing from a point-wise understanding of graphs to a more global view. We encourage students to become more involved with graphs by providing blank grids with appropriately scaled axes for most problems. These ready-made grids remove some of the drudgery of graphing and allow students to focus on the properties of the graphs, such as intercepts and slope, and on interpreting the information given by the graph. Later, we take advantage of graphing calculators to examine large numbers of examples and study them in more detail than is possible when every graph is plotted by hand. We consider more realistic models in which calculations by more traditional methods are difficult or impossible.

We have incorporated the use of graphing technology into the text wherever they can be used to enhance understanding. Technology use is not simply an add-on, but in many ways shapes the organization of the material. The text includes instructions for the TI-83 graphing calculator, but these can easily be adapted to any other graphing utility. We have not attempted to use all the features of the calculator or to teach calculator use for its own sake, but in all cases have let the mathematics suggest how technology should be used.

paragraphs.title: Content
paragraphs.p: Intermediate Algebra includes the material found in a typical algebra course, along with an introduction to curve-fitting. The order of topics and their presentation is organized around families of functions and their applications. Appendix A includes review material on polynomial products and factoring, laws of exponents, and facts from geometry. Appendix B provides a note on the structure of the real number system and an introduction to complex numbers.

introduction.p: In the debate over global warming, sea level is a reliable indicator of climate change, because it is affected by both melting glaciers and by the thermal expansion of sea water. During the 20th century, sea level rose by about 15 centimeters, compared to a fairly constant level for the previous 3,000 years.

Not surprisingly, scientists would like to understand the causes of sea-level change as thoroughly as possible, and to measure the rate of sea-level rise as accurately as possible. Using data from satellites and floats (mechanical devices drifting in the ocean), oceanographers at NASAâ€™s Jet Propulsion Laboratory have calculated that the sea level rose, on average, 3 millimeters (0.1 inches) per year between 1995 and 2005. The graph below shows the change in mean sea level, measured in millimeters, over that time period.

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) predicts that sea level could rise as much as 1 meter during the 21st century. If that happens, low-lying, densely populated areas in China, Southeast Asia, and the Nile Delta would become uninhabitable, as well as the Gulf Coast and Eastern Seaboard of the United States.

subsection.title: Tables, Graphs, and Equations

definition.title: Mathematical Model
definition.p: A mathematical modelmathematical model is a simplified description of reality that helps us understand a system or process.

subsection.p: We can use a model to analyze data, identify trends, and predict the effects of change. The first step in creating a model is to describe relationships between the variables involved.

statement.p: What is the first step in creating a mathematical model?

solution.p: Describe the relationships between the variables involved.

statement.p: What is the first step in creating a mathematical model?

li.p: Solve the equation.
Analyze data, identify trends, and predict the effects of change.
Describe the relationships between the variables involved.
Make a table of values.

solution.p: Describe the relationships between the variables involved.

subsection.p:
Starting from a description in words, we can represent the relationship by:
a table of values
a graph, or by
an algebraic equation

Each of these mathematical tools is useful in a different way.
A table of values lists specific data points with precise numerical values.
A graph is a visual display of the data. It is easier to spot trends and describe the overall behavior of the variables from a graph.
An algebraic equation is a compact summary of the model. It can be used to analyze the model and to make predictions.

subsection.p: In the examples that follow, observe the interplay among the three modeling tools and how each contributes to the model.

statement.p: In May 2005, the city of Lyons, France, started a bicycle rental program. Over 3,000 bicycles are available at 350 computerized stations around the city. Each of the 52,000 subscribers pays an annual 5 euro fee (about $7.20) and gets a PIN to access the bicycles. The bicycles rent for 1 euro per hour and can be returned to any station.
Your community decides to set up a similar program, charging a $5 subscription fee and $3 an hour for rental. (A fraction of an hour is charged as the corresponding fraction of $3).

li.p: Make a table of values showing the cost, C, of renting a bike for various lengths of time, t.
Plot the points on a graph. Draw a curve through the data points.
Write an equation for C in terms of t.

There is an initial fee of $5, and a rental fee of $3 per hour. To find the cost, we multiply the time by $3 per hour, and add the result to the $5 subscription fee. For example, the cost of a one-hour bike ride is \text{Cost}\amp=(\$5\text{ insurance fee})+(\$3\text{ per hour})\times(\alert{\text{one hour}})C\amp=5+3(\alert{1})=8 A one-hour bike ride costs $8.
We calculate the cost for the other values of t. and record the results in a table as shown below.

stack.p: Each pair of values represents a point on the graph. The first value gives the horizontal coordinate of the point, and the second value gives the vertical coordinate.
The points lie on a straight line, as shown in the figure. The line extends infinitely in only one direction, because negative values of t do not make sense here.

li.p: To write an equation, we let C represent the cost of the rental, and we use t for the number of hours:

statement.p: Write an equation for the cost C of renting a bicycle for t hours if the subscription fee is $7 and the rental fee is $2.50 per hour.

hint.p: Fill in the correct numbers.

subsection.title: Equations for Linear Models
subsection.p: The equation we wrote in the first Example is an example of a linear model, which describes a variable that increases or decreases at a constant rate.

definition.title: Linear Model
definition.p: A linearl modellinear model describes a variable that increases or decreases at a constant rate. It has the form \blert{y=(\text{starting value})+(\text{rate})\times t }

subsection.p: In the next example we see how a graph and its equation are related.

statement.p: Use the equation C=5+3\cdot t you found in to answer the following questions. Then show how to find the answers by using the graph.

li.p: How much will it cost to rent a bicycle for 6 hours?
How long can you bicycle for $18.50?

We substitute t=\alert{6} into the equation to find C=5+3(\alert{6})=23 A 6-hour bike ride will cost $23. The point P on the graph in the figure represents the cost of a 6-hour bike ride. The value on the C-axis at the same height as point P is 23, so a 6-hour bike ride costs $23.

sidebyside.p: We substitute C=\alert{18.50} into the equation and solve for t. \alert{18.50}\amp=5+3t13.50\amp=3tt\amp=4.5 For $18.50 Annelise can bicycle for 4\frac{1}{2} hours. The point Q on the graph represents an $18.50 bike ride. The value on the t-axis below point Q is 4.5, so $18.50 will buy a 4.5 hour bike ride.

subsection.p:
In , note the different algebraic techniques we used in parts (a) and (b):
In part (a) we were given a value of t and we evaluated the expression 5 + 3t to find C.
In part (b) we were given a value of C and we solved the equation C = 5 + 3t to find t.

statement.p: Consider the expression C = 5 + 3t. Finding a value of C when we know t is called the expression. Finding a value of t when we know C is called the equation.

subsection.p: In the examples above, the graph is increasing as t increases. In the next Example we consider a decreasing graph.

statement.p: Leon's camper has a 20-gallon gas tank, and he gets 12 miles to the gallon. (Note that getting 12 miles to the gallon is the same as using â€‹ \frac{1}{12} gallon of gas per mile.)

li.p: Write an equation for the amount of gasoline, g, left in Leon's tank after he has driven for d miles.
Make a table of values for the equation.
Graph the equation,
If Leon has less than 5 gallons of gas left, how many miles has he driven since his last fill-up? Illustrate on the graph.

We use the form for a linear model, y=(\text{starting value})+(\text{rate})\times t However, in this problem, instead of variables y and t, we use g and d. Leon's fuel tank started with 20 gallons, and the amount of gasoline is decreasing at a rate of \frac{1}{12} gallon for every mile that he drives. Thus, g=20-\frac{1}{12}d
Every time Leon drives 12 miles, he uses another gallon of gasoline. So, to make the calculations easier, we choose values that are divisible by 12.
We scale the values of d along the horizontal axis, and the values of g along the vertical axis. Then we plot the points from the table and connect with a line, as shown in the figure below.

If Leon has less than 5 gallons of gasoline left, then g\lt 5, as shown on the g-axis. Using our model from part (a), we solve the inequality. 20-\frac{1}{12}d \amp \lt 5 -\frac{1}{12}d \amp \lt -15 d \amp\gt 180 Leon has driven at least 180 miles. The solution is shown on the graph below.

subsection.p: In part (d) of the previous Example we used an inequality to answer the question. We use inequalities to model English phrases such as "less than," "more than," "at least," and "at most."

Frank plants a dozen corn seedlings, each 6 inches tall. With plenty of water and sunlight they will grow approximately 2 inches per day. Complete the table of values for the height, h, of the seedlings after t days.

li.p: Complete the table of values for the height, h of the seedlings after t days.
Write an equation for the height, h, of the seedlings in terms of the number of days, t, since they were planted.
Graph the equation on the grid. Label the axes with the correct variables.

48 in

14 is the initial height of the plants in inches. 1.5 is the number of inches they grow each day.

statement.p: On October 31, Betty and Paul fill their 250-gallon oil tank for their heater. Beginning in November they use an average of 15 gallons of oil per week.

li.p: Complete the table of values for the amount of oil, A, left in the tank after w weeks.
Write an equation that expresses the amount of oil, A, in terms of the number of weeks, w, since October 31.
Graph the equation.

subsection.p: The coordinates of the intercepts are easy to find.

li.p: To find the x-intercept, we set y = 0 and solve for x.
To find the y-intercept, we set x = 0 and solve for y.

statement.p: In of , we graphed an equation, g=20-\frac{1}{12}d , for the amount of gasoline, g, left in Leon's tank after he has driven for d miles. Find the intercepts of the graph.

solution.p: To find the d-intercept, we set g =â€¯0 and solve for d.
The d-intercept is (240, 0). To find the g-intercept, we set d = 0 and solve for g. g = 20â€¯âˆ’â€¯\frac{1}{12}(\alert{0}) = 20 The g-intercept is (0, 20).

subsection.title: Meaning of the Intercepts
subsection.p: The intercepts of a graph give us information about the situation it models.

statement.p: What do the intercepts of the graph in the Example above tell us about the problem situation?

solution.p: The d-intercept tells us that when d = 240, gâ€¯=â€¯0, or that when Leon has traveled 240 miles, he has 0 gallons of gasoline left; the fuel tank is empty. The g-intercept tells us that when d = 0, g = 20, or that when Leon has traveled 0 miles, he has 20 gallons of gasoline left. The fuel tank holds 20 gallons when full.

subsection.title: General Form for a Linear Equation
subsection.p: The graphs of the equations we have seen so far are all portions of straight lines. For this reason such equations are called linear equations.

The order of the terms in the equation does not matter. For example, the equation in of \amp C=5+3t \amp \amp \text{ can be written equivalently as } \amp -3t + C=5 and the equation in of that section, \amp g=20-\frac{1}{12}d \amp \amp \text{ can be written as } \amp \frac{1}{12}d+g=20
This form of a linear equation, Ax +By = C, is called the general form.

definition.title: General Form for a Linear Equation

authored.pg-code: $which1 = RadioButtons( ["\(y=mx+b\)", "\(Ax+By=C\)", "Any equation whose graph is a straight line.", "Set \(x=0\) and solve for \(y\)."], 1, );

statement.p: What is the general form of a linear equation?
What is the general form of a linear equation?

li.p: Any equation whose graph is a straight line.
Set x=0 and solve for y.

subsection.p: Some linear models are easier to use when they are written in the general form.

statement.p: The manager at Albert's Appliances has $3000 to spend on advertising for the next fiscal quarter. A 30-second spot on television costs $150 per broadcast, and a 30-second radio ad costs $50.

li.p: The manager decides to buy x television ads and y radio ads. Write an equation relating x and y.
Make a table of values showing several choices for x and y.
Plot the points from your table, and graph the equation.
Each television ad costs $150, so x ads will cost $150x. Similarly, y radio ads will cost $50y. The manager has $3000 to spend, so the sum of the costs must be $3000. Thus, 150x+50y=3000

We choose some values of x, and solve the equation for the corresponding value of y. For example, if x=\alert{10} then 150(\alert{10})+50y\amp=3001500+50y\amp=300050y\amp=1500y\amp=30 If the manager buys 10 television ads, she can also buy 30 radio ads. You can verify the other entries in the table.

sidebyside.p: We plot the points from the table. All the solutions lie on a straight line.

hint.p: Use the general form for a linear equation. What is the total amount of money the manager will spend?

subsection.title: Intercept Method of Graphing
subsection.p: Because we really need only two points to graph a linear equation, we might as well find the intercepts and use them to draw the graph.

subsection.title: Solving for y in Terms of x

li.p: Solve the equation 4x-3y=6 for y in terms of x.
Write the equation y=-9-\dfrac{3}{2}x in general linear form.

We first isolate the y-term on one side of the equation. 4x-3y \amp = 6 \amp\amp \glert{\text{Subtract }4x\text{ from both sides.}} -3y \amp = 6 -4x\amp\amp \glert{\text{Divide both sides by } {-3}.} \frac{-3y}{-3} \amp = \frac{6-4x}{-3} \amp\amp \glert{\text{Simplify: divide each term by }{-3}.} y \amp -2 + \frac{4}{3}x

Write the equation in the form Ax+By=C. y \amp = -9-\frac{3}{2}x\amp\amp \glert{\text{Add } \frac{3}{2}x \text{ to both sides.}} \frac{3}{2}x+y \amp = -9 We can write the equation with integer coefficients by clearing the fractions. We multiply both sides of the equation by \alert{2} . \alert{2}\left(\frac{3}{2}x+y \right) \amp = -9(\alert{2}) 3x+2y \amp = -18

subsection.warning:
Do not confuse solving for y in terms of x with finding the y-intercept. Compare:
In Example 5a, we solved 4x âˆ’ 3y = 6 for y in terms of x to get y = -2 +\frac{4}{3}x . This is still an equation in two variables; it is just another (equivalent) form of the original equation.
To find the y-intercept of the same equation, we first set x = 0, then solve for y, as follows: 4(0) âˆ’ 3y \amp = 6y = âˆ’2
This gives us a particular point on the graph, namely, (0, âˆ’2); the point whose x-coordinate is 0.

subsection.title: Equations and Solutions

definition.title: Solution
definition.p: A solutionsolution of an equation is a value of the variable that makes the equationtrue.

subsection.p: For example, x = âˆ’2 is a solution of the equation 4x^3 + 5x^2 -8x = 4 because 4(-2)^3 + 5(-2)^2 - 8(-2) = -2 + 20 + 16 = 4.

statement.p: Which of the following equations are quadratic?

solution.p: (A) and (D) are quadratic.

statement.p: Which of the following equations are quadratic?

solution.p: (A) and (D) are quadratic.

subsection.p: A linear equation has at most one solution. We find the solution by transforming the equation into a simpler equivalent equation whose solution is obvious.

statement.p: Solve the equation 3(2x-5)-4x=2x-(6-3x)

solution.p: We begin by simplifying each side of the equation. 3(2x-5)-4x\amp =2x-(6-3x)\amp\amp\glert{\text{Apply the distrubutive law. }} 6x-15-4x\amp =2x-6+3x\amp\amp\glert{\text{Combine like terms. }} 2x-15\amp =5x-6\amp\amp\glert{\text{Add } {-5x+15} \text{ to both sides} } -3x \amp = 9 \amp\amp \glert{\text{Divide both sides by }{-3.}} x\amp = -3 The solution is -3. You can check that substituting x=-3 into the original equation produces a true statement.

statement.p: Find the solution of the equation 16 - 2(3x - 1) = 4x + 2(x - 3).
Find the solution of the equation 16 - 2(3x - 1) = 4x + 2(x - 3)\text{.}

subsection.title: Linear Inequalities
subsection.p: Although a linear equation can have at most one solution, a linear inequality can have many solutions. For example, complete the table of values for the expression 5 âˆ’ 2x:
Now use your table to list at least three solutions of the inequality 5 - 2x \lt 2.

statement.p: Use algebra to solve the inequality 5 -2x \lt 2.

solution.p: We begin by isolating the term containing the variable, just as we dowhen solving a linear equation. We subtract 5 from both sides to obtain -2x \lt -3 Then we divide both sides by âˆ’2 to find x\gt \frac{-3}{-2}\amp =\frac{3}{2}\amp\amp\glert{\text{Reverse the direction of the inequality.}} Any value of x greater than \frac{3}{2} is a solution of the inequality. Because we cannot list all of these solutions, we often illustrate them as a graph on a number line, as shown below.

subsection.p: In the Example above, we used the following rule for solving linear inequalities.

assemblage.p: If we multiply or divide both sides of an inequality by a negative number, wemust reverse the direction of the inequality.

subsection.p: Other than the rule stated in the box above, the rules for solving a linear inequality are the same as the rules for solving a linear equation.

subsection.title: Equations in Two Variables
subsection.p: An equation in two variables, such as -3x+4y=24 has many solutions. Each solution consists of an ordered pair of values, one for x and one for y, that together satisfy the equation (make the equation true.)

The ordered pair (4,3) is not a solution, because it does not satify the equation. -3(\alert{4})+4(\alert{3})=-12+12=0\ne 24

subsection.title: What is the Graph of an Equation?

definition.title: Graph
definition.p: The graphgraph of an equation in two variables is just a picture of all its solutions.

subsection.p: You might think it would be difficult to find all the solutions of an equation, but for a linear equation Ax + By = C, we can at least illustrate the solutions: all thesolutions lie on a straight line. (Later on we can prove that this is true.)

statement.p: True or false?

li.p: All the solutions of a linear equation in two variables lie on a straight line.
The equation -3x + 4y = 24 is a linear equation.
The graph of an equation in two variables is a picture of its solutions.
If a point lies on the graph of an equation, it is a solution of the equation.

sidebyside.p:
The figure shows a graph of the equation Ax + By = C. Which of the following equations are true?
24B=C
Ap+Bq=C
Ag+Bh=C

li.p: The point (0, 24) lies on the graph, so x = 0, y = 24 is a solution of the equation. Thus, A \cdot 0 + B \cdot 24 = C, or 24B = C is a true statement.
The point (p, q) does not lie on the graph, so x = p, y = q does not satisfy the equation, and A p+ B q = C is a not true.
The point (g,h ) does lie on the graph, so x = g, y = h does satisfy the equation, and A g+ B h = C, is a true.

subsection.title: Graphical Solution of Equations
subsection.p: We can use graphs to find solutions to equations in one variable.

statement.p: Use the graph of y = 285 - 15x to solve the equation 150 = 285 - 15x.

stack.p: Compare the two equations in the problem. In the equation we wan to solve, y has been replaced by 150. We begin by locating the point P on the graph for which y = 150. Next we find the x-coordinate of point P by drawing an imaginary line from P straight down to the x-axis. The x-coordinate of P is x = 9.
Thus, P is the point (9,150), and x = 9 when y = 150. The solution we seek is x = 9.

solution.p: You can verify the solution algebraically by substituting x = \alert{9} into the equation:

subsection.p:
The relationship between an equation and its graph is an important one. For the previous example, make sure you understand that the following three statement sare equivalent.
The point (9, 150) lies on the graph of y = 285 - 15x.
The ordered pair (9, 150) is a solution of the equation y = 285 - 15x.
x=9 is a solution of the equation 150 = 285 - 15x.

Step 2: Find the x-coordinate of your point P.

subsection.title: Graphical Solution of Inequalities
subsection.p: We can also use graphs to solve inequalities. Consider the inequality 285-15x \ge 150 To solve this inequality means finding all values of x that make the expression 285 -15x greater than or equal to 150. We could begin by trying some values of x. Here is a table obtained by evaluating 285 âˆ’ 15x.
From the table, we see that values of x less than or equal to 8 are solutions ofthe inequality, but we have not checked all possible x-values. We can get a more complete picture from a graph.

statement.p: Here is a graph of the equation y = 285 - 15x. Use the graph to solve the inequality 285 - 15x \gt 150

sidebyside.p: We look for points on the graph with y-coordinates greater than or equal to 150. These points are shown in color. Which x-values produced these points with y-values greater or equal to 150? We can read the x-coordinates by dropping straight down to the x-axis, as shown by the arows. For example, the x-value corresponding to 285-15x=150 is x=9. For larger values of 285-15x, we must choose x-values less than 9. Thus the solutions are all values of x less than or equal to 9, as shown on the x-axis.

Step 2: Find the x-coordinate of the point P.
Step 3: Which points on the graph have y \lt 14? Mark them on the graph.
Step 4: Find the x-coordinates of the points in Step 3. Mark them all on the x-axis.
Verify your solution algebraically.

subsection.title: Using a Graphing Utility
subsection.p: We can use a graphing utility to graph equations if they are written in the form y = (\text{expression in }x). On most calculators, we follow three steps.

li.p: Press Y= and enter the equation you wish to graph.
Press WINDOW and select a graphing window.
Press GRAPH.

subsection.p: Choosing a graphing window corresponds to drawing the x- and y-axes and marking a scale on each axis when we graph by hand. The standard graphing window displays values from -10 to 10 on both axes. We can press the ZOOM key and then the number 6 to select this window.

statement.p: Use a graphing utility to graph the equation 3x + 2y = 16.

solution.p: First, we solve the equation for y in terms of x. 3x+2y \amp = 16\amp\amp\glert{\text{Subtract } 3x \text{ from both sides.}} 2y\amp = -3x+16 \amp\amp\glert{\text{Divide both sides by 2.}} y\amp = \frac{-3x}{2}+\frac{16}{2}\amp\amp \glert{\text{Simplify.}} y\amp= -1.5x+8

sidebyside.p: Now press Y= and enter -1.5x+8 after Y_1=. (Use the negation key, (-), to enter -1.5x; do not use the subtraction key.) We choose the standard graphing window by pressing ZOOM 6. The graph is shown at right.

subsection.p: When you want to erase the graph, press Y= and then press CLEAR. This deletes the expression following Y_1.

We press TRACE, and a "bug" begins flashing on the display. The coordinates of the bug appear at the bottom of the display, as shown in the figure. We use the left and right arrows to move the bug along the graph. You can check that the coordinates of the point (2, -10.6) do satisfy the equation y = -2.6x - 5.4.

subsection.title: Glacier Melt
subsection.p: Glaciers around the world are retreating at accelerating rates, and many lower-latitude mountain glaciers may disappear entirely within decades. The meltwaterfrom these smaller glaciers contributed as much as 40% to the total rise in sea level over the 1990s.

By measuring the change in ice and snow height at fixed points and multiplying by the surface area of the glacier, scientists calculate the total volume of water lost from land-based glaciers. Dividing this volume by the surface area of the world's oceans gives the resulting change in sea level.
The graphs below show the change in thickness of the land-based glaciers overthe past 5 years, and the rise in sea level attributed to their melting.

image.description: graphs of change in glacier thickness and resulting rise in sea level

assemblage.p: A rate is a type of ratio that compares two quantities with different units.

subsection.p: In the example below, notice that each rate has units of the form \dfrac{\text{something}}{\text{something else}} , which we read as "something per something else."

statement.p: Caryn bought 7 used paperback novels for a total of $2.45. Use a ratio to calculate the price per book.

md.mrow: \frac{\text{total cost in dollars}}{\text{number of books}} = \frac{2.45 \text{ dollars}}{7 \text{ books}} = 0.35 \text{ dollars/book}

solution.p: The novels were priced at a rate of $0.35 per book.

definition.title: Rate of Change
definition.p: A rate of changerate of change is a special kind of ratio that compares the change in two quantities or variables.

statement.p: Gregor is driving across Montana. At 1 pm his trip odometer reads 189 miles, and at 4 pm it reads 360 miles. Calculate Gregor's average speed as a rate of change.

solution.p: We have two variablestime, t, and distance, dand the following data points:

Gregor's speed is the ratio of the distance he traveled to the time it took. The distance he traveled is the change in his odometer reading (from 189 miles to 360 miles), and the time it took is the change in the clock reading (from 1 pm to 4 pm).The units of this ratio are miles per hour.

stack.p: How do we see the rate of change on a graph? Let's consider the example above. The graph shows Gregor's distance, d, at time t. We plot the two data points, (1, 189) and (4, 360), and draw a straight line joining them. We can illustrate \Delta d and \Delta t by vertical and horizontal line segments, as shown on the graph.

The rate of change of distance with respect to time, or speed, is the ratio of \Delta d to \Delta t. It measures how much d changes for each unit increase in t, or how far Gregor travels in each hour. This quantity, the ratio \dfrac{\Delta d}{\Delta t} , is the slope of the line.

definition.title: Slope of a Line

subsection.p: How does slope measure the steepness of a line? Study the three examples below:

stack.p: For each 1 unit increase in x:
y increases by 2 units m=\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=\frac{2}{1}=2
y increases by \frac{3}{2} units m=\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=\frac{3}{2}
y decreases by 2 units m=\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=\frac{-2}{1}=-2

subsection.p: From the examples on the previous page, we can make the following observations:

li.p: For positive slopes, the larger the value of m, the more the y-value increases for each unit increase in x, and the more we climb up as our location changes from left to right. (So graph A is steeper than graph B.)
If y decreases as we move from left to right, then \Delta y is negative when \Delta x is positive, so their ratio (the slope) is negative. (See graph C.)

subsection.title: Interpreting Slope as a Rate
subsection.p: The slope of a line measures the rate of change of y with respect to x.

statement.p: The graph shows the altitude, a (in feet), of a skier t minutes after getting on a ski lift.

li.p: Choose two points on the graph and compute the slope, including units.
Explain what the slope measures in this problem.
Write a linear model for a in terms of t.
We choose the points (2,400) and (4, 700), as shown on the graph. Then m=\frac{\Delta a}{\Delta t} = \frac{300 \text{ feet}}{2 \text{ minutes}} = 150 \text{ feet/minute}
The slope gives the rate of change of altitude with respect to time. The skier rises at a rate of 150 feet per minute.

A linear model has the form y = (\text{starting value}) + (\text{rate}) \times t From the graph, we see that at t = 0 the skier's altitude was a = 100, and we calculated the rate of change of altitude as 150 feet per minute. Substitutingthese values into the formula, we find a = 100 + 150t

subsection.title: Lines Have Constant Slope

assemblage.p: The slope of a line is constant: no matter which two points you pick to computethe slope, you will always get the same value.

stack.p: For the line shown in the figure, try computing the slope using the points P and Q, and then using the points G and H. In each case, you should find that the slope is \frac{3}{2} .

Here is another way to look at slopes. If we start at any point on the line shown and move 9 units to the right, what value of \Delta y will bring us back to the line? We can use the slope formula with \Delta x=9.

md.mrow: m \amp=\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} \amp\amp\glert{\text{Substitute the known values.}}

subsection.p: You can use the graph to check this result for yourself; try starting at the point (-6,-3) .

The fact that lines have constant slope has two important consequences. First because m is constant for a given line, we can use the formula m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} to find \Delta y when we know \Delta x , or to find\Delta x when we know \Delta y .

subsection.p: Here is a second consequence of the fact that lines have constant slope: We can tell whether a collection of data points lies on a straight line by computing slopes. If the slope between any two data points is the same, the points lie on a straight line.

From 1960 to 2003, the land-based glaciers decreased in thickness by about 8 meters (or 0.008 km). The total area of those glaciers is 785,000 square kilometers. Calculate the total volume of water released by melting. (Hint: \text{Volume}= \text{area}\times \text{thickness} )

subsection.title: Polar Ice
subsection.p:
Three main factors influence the energy balance of the Earth and its temperature:
The total energy influx from the sun
The chemical composition of the atmosphere
The ability of the Earth's surface to reflect light, or albedo

Because polar ice reflects light from the sun, the radiation balance over an ice-covered ocean is very different from the balance over an open ocean. Sea ice also influences deep-ocean circulation, and small changes in ocean currents can have a large effect on coastal and global climate. Thus, the ice component of the climate system, called the cryosphere, plays an important role in the Earth's radiation balance.

General circulation models predict that global warming over the next few decades will occur mainly in the polar regions. As polar ice begins to melt, less sunlight is reflected into space, which raises the overall temperature and fuels further melting. This process is called ice albedo feedback.

Since satellite monitoring began in 1979, Arctic sea ice cover has decreased about 10% per decade, falling to a startling new low in 2007. NASA scientists are working to understand this sudden decline and what it means for climate change. "It really is imperative that we try to understand the interactions between the ice, ocean and atmosphere," according to senior scientist Josefi no Comiso.

Numerous factors influence the freezing point of sea water, including its salinity, or mineral content. Unlike tropical oceans, which are temperature-stratified (water near the surface is warmer), the Arctic Ocean is salinity-stratified. In this Lesson we'll develop a formula for the freezing temperature of water in terms of its salinity.

The graph shows the amount of garbage G, in tons, that has been deposited at a dumpsite t years after new regulations go into effect.
Choose two points on the graph and compute the slope, including units.
Find an equation for the graph shown.
State the meaning of the slope and the vertical intercept.

li.p:
Two points on the line are (0, 25) and (10, 150) The slope is
m=\frac{\Delta G}{\Delta t}=\frac{125\text{ tons}}{10\text{ years}}=12.5 \text{ tons/year}

The vertical intercept of the graph is (0,25), so b=25, and
G=mt+b = 12.5t + 25
The slope tells us that garbage is accumulating at a rate of 12.5 tons per year. The vertical intercept tells us that when the new regulations went into effect, the dump held 25 tons of garbage.

subsection.title: Coordinate Formula for Slope
subsection.p: Slope measures the change in one variable with respect to unit changes in another.To calculate the net change between two points on a number line, we can subtract their coordinates. \blert{\text{net change} = \text{final value} - \text{starting value}}

For example, if you walk from 3^\text{rd} street to 8^\text{th} street, your distance, s, from the center of town has increased by 5 blocks, or \Delta s = 8 - 3 = 5 If the temperature T drops from 28\degree to 22\degree, it has decreased by 6\degree, or \Delta T = 22-28 = -6

assemblage.p: The net change is positive if the variable increases, and negative if it decreases.

sidebyside.p: Thus, for the graph shown at right, the net change in t-coordinate from P to Q is \Delta t = 51 - (-23) = 74 We can use the notion of net change to calculate slopes. Recall the coordinate formula for computing slope.

assemblage.title: Coordinate Formula for Slope

authored.pg-code: $which = RadioButtons( ["The slope cannot be zero.", "The two points cannot be the same.", "The denominator of a fraction cannot be zero.", "The denominator must equal 1."], 2, );

statement.p: In the coordinate formula for slope, why do we require that x_1 \ne x_2?

solution.p: The denominator of a fraction cannot be zero.

statement.p: In the coordinate formula for slope, why do we require that x_1 \ne x_2\text{?}

li.p: The slope cannot be zero.
The two points cannot be the same.
The denominator of a fraction cannot be zero.
The denominator must equal 1.

solution.p: The denominator of a fraction cannot be zero.

subsection.p: Notice that the numerator of the slope formula, y_2 - y_1, gives the net change in y, and the denominator, x_2 - x_1, gives the net change in x. The coordinate formula is equivalent to our definition of slope, m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} , and is useful for computing slope when we know the coordinates of two points on a line.

subsection.title: Point-Slope Formula
subsection.p: Now consider using the slope formula for a different problem. If we know the slope of a line and the coordinates of one point on the line, we can use the coordinate formula for slope to find the y-coordinate of any other point on the line. Instead of evaluating the formula to find m, we substitute the values we know for m and (x_1, y_1). Then we plug in the x-coordinate of the unknown point and solve for y.

statement.p: A line has slope \dfrac{-3}{4} and passes through the point (1,-4) . Which equation can you use to find the y-coordinate of the point on the line with the x-coordinate of 6?
A line has slope \dfrac{-3}{4} and passes through the point (1,-4) \text{.} Which equation can you use to find the y-coordinate of the point on the line with the x-coordinate of 6?

subsection.p: There is only one line that passes through a given point and has a given slope. So, if we know the slope of a particular line and one point on the line, we can find its equation. Remember that the equation is really just a formula that gives the y-coordinate of any point on the line in terms of its x-coordinate. To find the equation, we can use the coordinate formula for slope.

li.p: Graph the line that passes through the point (1, -4) and has \text{slope}=\dfrac{-3}{4} .
Find an equation for the line in part (a).

sidebyside.p: We first plot the given point, (1,-4), and then use the slope to find another point on the line. The slope is m=\dfrac{-3}{4}=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} , so starting from (1,-4) we move down 3 units and then 4 units to the right. This brings us to the point (5,-7). We draw the line through these two points.

li.p: To solve for y we first multiply both sides by xâ€¯âˆ’â€¯1. \alert{(x-1)}\frac{-3}{4}\amp = \frac{y+4}{x-1}\alert{(x-1)} \frac{-3}{4}(x-1)\amp = y+4 \amp\amp \glert{\text{Apply the distributive law.}} \frac{-3}{4}x +\frac{3}{4} \amp = y+4 \amp\amp \glert{\text{Subtract 4 from both sides.}} \frac{-3}{4}x -\frac{13}{4} \amp = y \amp\amp \glert{\frac{3}{4}-4=\frac{3}{4}-\frac{16}{4}=\frac{-13}{4}}

assemblage.title: Point-Slope Form
assemblage.p:
The equation of the line that passes through the point (x_1, y_1) and has slope m is y = y_1 + m(x-x_1) You may also see the formula written in an alternate version:
y - y_1 = m(x-x_1)\qquad\text{ or }\qquad \frac{y-y_1}{x-x_1}=m

statement.p: Use the point-slope form to find the equation of the line that passes throughthe point (-3, 5) and has slope -1.4.
Answer:
Use the point-slope form to find the equation of the line that passes throughthe point (-3, 5) and has slope -1.4\text{.}
Answer:

subsection.title: Finding a Linear Model
subsection.p: If we have two data points for a linear model, we can find its equation. We use two steps: first we compute the slope of the line, then we use the point-slope formula.

statement.p:
It cost a bicycle company $9000 to make 50 touring bikes in its first month of operation and $15,000 to make 125 bikes during its second month.
Find a linear equation for the company's monthly production cost, C, in terms of the number of bikes made, x.
State the slope and vertical intercept of your line, including units. What do they tell you about the problem?

li.p: We first find two data points, (x, C), from the information given.

Step 1: Compute the slope of the line.
m=\frac{C_2-C_1}{x_2-x_1}= \frac{15,000-9000}{125-5} = 80

Step 2: Apply the point-sope formula, using (50,9000) for (x_1,y_1)
C\amp=C_1 +m(x-x_1)
\amp=9000 +80(x-50)
\amp=9000 +80x-4000
The equation is C=5000+80x

The slope is 80 dollars per bike, and it tells us the cost of producing each bike. The vertical intercept is 5000, and it tells us that the bicycle company's fixed costs (before production begins) are $5000.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p: In this section, we studied three different formulas associated with linear equations: the slope-intercept formula, the coordinate formula for slope, and the point-slope formula. How are these formulas related, and how are they different?

li.p:
What is the difference between the slope formula
m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}
and the point-slope formula
m= \frac{y-y_1}{x-x_1} ?
They are really the same formula, but they are used for different purposes:
The slope formula is used to calculate the slope when we know two points. We know (x_1, y_1) and (x_2, y_2), and we are looking for m.
The point-slope formula is used to find the equation of a line. We know (x_1, y_1) and m, and we are looking for y = mx + b.

subsection.title: Key Concepts
subsection.p:
A mathematical model is a simplified description of reality that helps us understand a system or process.
We can describe a relationship between variables with a table of values, a graph, or an equation.
Linear models have equations of the form:
y =â€¯(\blert{\text{starting value}}) + (\blert{\text{rate of change}}) \cdot x
The general form for a linear equation is: Ax + By = C.
We can use the intercepts to graph a line. The intercepts are also useful for interpreting a model.
The graph of an equation in two variables is just a picture of all its solutions.
Lines have constant slope.
The slope of a line gives us the rate of change of one variable with respect to another.
Formulas for Linear Models
slope: \qquad\qquad m=\dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \dfrac{Y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} , x_1 \ne x_2
slope-intercept form: \qquad\qquad y=b+mx
point-slopet form: \qquad\qquad y=y_1+m(x-x_1)
The slope-intercept form is useful when we know the initial value and the rate of change.
The point-slope form is useful when we know the rate of change and one point on the line. .

introduction.p: You may have heard that mathematics is the language of science. In fact, professionals in nearly every discipline take advantage of mathematical methods to analyze data, identify trends, and predict the effects of change. This process is called mathematical modeling. A model is a simplified representation of reality that helps us understand a process or phenomenon. Because it is a simplification, a model can never be completely accurate. Instead, it should focus on those aspects of the real situation that will help us answer specific questions. Here is an example.

The world's population is growing at different rates in different nations. Many factors, including economic and social forces, influence the birth rate. Is there a connection between birth rates and education levels? The figure shows the birth rate plotted against the female literacy rate in 148 countries. Although the data points do not all lie precisely on a line, we see a generally decreasing trend: the higher the literacy rate, the lower the birth rate. The regression line provides a model for this trend, and a tool for analyzing the data. In this chapter we study the properties of linear models and some techniques for fitting a linear model to data.

image.description: Plot of birth rate vs female literacy

subsection.title: Shrinking Rain Forest

stack.p: The Amazon Basin in South America contains over half of the planet's rain forest. The Amazon rain forest is home to the largest collection of plant and animal species in the world, including more than one-third of all living species. During the 1960s, colonists began cutting down the rain forest to clear land for agriculture. The construction of the Trans-Amazonian Highway in thee arly 1970s opened large forest areas to development by settlers and commercial interests, increasing the rate of deforestation.

Environmentalists are concerned about the loss of biodiversity which will result from destruction of the forest, and about the release of the carbon contained within the vegetation, which could accelerate global warming.

In Brazil, the Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (INPE, or National Institute of Space Research) uses Landsat satellite photos to monitor the pace of deforestation. According to their data, the original Amazon rain forest biome in Brazil of 4,100,000 square kilometers was reduced to 3,413,000 square kilometers by 2005, representing a loss of 16.8%. The figures for 1987 to 2006 are shown at right, and a plot of the data appears below

subsection.p: Although the data points do not all lie exactly on a straight line, they are very close. One question we might ask is: If deforestation continues at the same rate, when will the Amazon rain forest disappear completely? In this section we learn to find a linear model that approximates a data set.

subsection.title: Line of Best Fit
subsection.p: In most cases, a mathematical model is not a perfect description of reality. Many factors can affect empirical data, including measurement error, environmental conditions, and the influence of related variables. Nonetheless, we can often findan equation that approximates the data in a useful way.

statement.p: The table shows the minimum wage in the US at five-year intervals. (Source: Economic Policy Institute)

li.p: Let t represent the number of years after 1960, and plot the data. Is the data linear?
Draw a line that "fits" the data.

The graph shown is called a scatterplot. The data are not strictly linear, because the slope is not constant: from 1960 to 1965, the minimum wage increased at an average rate of \dfrac{1.25-1.00}{5}=0.05 dollars per year, and from 1970 to 1975, the minimum wage increased at a rate of \dfrac{2.10-1.60}{5}=0.10 dollars per year. However, the data points do appear to lie close to an imaginary line.

sidebyside.p: We would like to draw a line that comes as close as possible to all the data points, even though it may not pass precisely through any of them. In particular, we try to adjust the line so that we have the same number of points above the line and below the line. One possible solution is shown in the figure at right

subsection.p: A line that fits the data in a scatterplot is called a regression line. Drawing aregression line by eye is a subjective process. In the Activities Workbook we'll use acalculator to compute a particular regression line called the least-squares regression line, which is widely used in statistics and modeling.

We can still find an equation for a line of best fit using the point-slope formula. We choose two points on the line whose coordinates we can estimate fairly accurately. Note that these two points need not be any of the original data points.

subsection.title: Line of Best Fit

statement.p: An outdoor snack bar collected the following data showing the number of cups of cocoa, C, they sold when the high temperature for the day was T\degree Celsius.

li.p: Make a scatterplot of the data, and draw a regression line
Read values from your line for the number of cups of cocoa that will be sold when the temperature is 8\degree\text{C} and when the temperature is 16\degree\text{C}.
Find an equation for the regression line.
Use your equation to predict the number of cups of cocoa that will be sold when the temperature is 9\degree\text{C}, and when the temperature is 24\degree\text{C}
The scatterplot and a regression line are shown in the figure.

The regression line need not pass through any of the data points, but it should be as close as possible. We try to draw the regression line so that there are an equal number of data points above and below the line.

The points (8, 32) and (16, 12) appear to lie on the regression line. According to this model, the snack bar will sell 32 cups of cocoa when the temperature is 8\degree\text{C}, and 12 cups when it is 16\degree\text{C}. These values are close to the actual data, but not exact.

To find an equation for the regression line, we use two points on the linenot data points! We will use (8, 32) and (16, 12). First we compute the slope
m=\frac{C_2-C_1}{T_2-T_1}=\frac{12-32}{16-8}=-2.5
Next, we apply the point-slope formula. We'll use the point (16, 12).
C\amp= C_1+m(T-T_1)
C\amp= 12-2.5(T-16)
C\amp= -2.5T+52

When T=\alert{9},
C=-2.5(\alert{9})+52=29.5
We predict that the snack bar will sell 29 or 30 cups of cocoa when the temperature is 9\degree\text{C}. When T = \alert{24},
C=-2.5(\alert{24})+52=-8
Because the snack bar cannot sell -8 cups of cocoa, this prediction is not useful. (What is the Fahrenheit equivalent of 24Â°C?)

subsection.p: Using a regression line to estimate values between known data points is called interpolation. If the data points lie fairly close to the regression line, then interpolation will usually give a fairly accurate estimate. In the Example above, the estimate of 29 or 30 cups of cocoa at 9\degree\text{C} seems reasonable in the context of the data.

Making predictions beyond the range of known data is called extrapolation. Extrapolation can often give useful information, but if we try to extrapolate too far beyond our data, we may get unreasonable results. The conditions that produced the data may no longer hold, as in the Example above, or other unexpected conditions may arise to alter the situation.

statement.p:
True or false.
A scatterplot is a type of linear model.
A regression line should give the same y-values as the data points.
We use interpolation to estimate the y-value at a data point.
Extrapolation is usually more reliable than interpolation.

solution.p: The statements are all false.

subsection.title: Scatterplots
subsection.p: The data in a scatterplot may show a linear trend, even though the individual points are not clustered closely around a line. Scattering of data is common in the social sciences, where many variables may influence a particular situation. Nonetheless, by analyzing the data, we may be able to detect a connection between some of the variables.

subsection.title: Systems of Equations
subsection.p: A biologist wants to know the average weights of two species of birds in a wildlife preserve. She sets up a feeder whose platform is actually a scale and mounts a camera to monitor the feeder. She waits until the feeder is occupied only by members of the two species she is studying, robins and thrushes. Then she takes a picture, which records the number of each species on the scale and the total weight registered.

This pair of equations is an example of a linear systemlinear system of two equations in two unknowns (or a 2\times 2 linear system, for short). A solutionsolution to the system is an ordered pair of numbers, (t, r), that satisfies both equations in the system.

statement.p: Choose the solution of the system: 3x-2y \amp = 194x+5y \amp = 10
Choose the solution of the system:

subsection.title: Solving Systems by Graphing

sidebyside.p: Every point on the graph of an equation represents a solution to that equation. A solution to both equations must be a point that lies on both graphs. Therefore, a solution to the system is a point where the two graphs intersect. The figure at right shows a graph of the system about robins and thrushes. The two lines appear to intersect at the point (4, 6), so we expect that the values t = \alert{4} and r = \alert{6} are the solution to the system. We can check by verifying that these values satisfy both equations in the system.

True or false.
The point where two lines cross is called the intercept
The intercepts of a line are the points where it intersects the axes.
The solution of a system may occur at an intercept.
The words intercept and intersect mean the same thing

solution.p: We set the graphing window to

and enter the two equations. We can see in the figure that the two lines intersect in the third quadrant. We use the TRACE key to find the coordinates of the intersection point, (-2,-3). The solution to the system is x=-2, y=-3.

subsection.p: The values we obtain from a calculator may be only approximations, so it is a good idea to check the solution algebraically. In the example above, we find that both equations are true when we substitute x = \alert{-2} and y=\blert{-3}. \blert{-3}\amp = 1.7(\alert{-2})+0.4\amp\amp \glert{\text{True}}\blert{-3}\amp = 4.2(\alert{-2})+5.2\amp\amp \glert{\text{True}}

subsection.title: The Intersect Feature
subsection.p: Because the TRACE feature does not show every point on a graph, we may not find the exact solution to a system by tracing the graphs.

statement.p: Solve the system 3x - 2.8y \amp= 21.062x + 1.2y \amp= 5.3

solution.p: We can graph this system in the standard window by solving each equation for y. We enter Y_1\amp = (21.06 - 3X)/-2.8Y_2\amp = (5.3 - 2X)/1.2 and then press ZOOM 6. If we trace along the graph to the intersection point, we will not find the same coordinates on both lines. The intersection point is not displayed in this window. Instead, we can use the intersect feature of the calculator.

Using the arrow keys, we position the Trace bug as close to the intersection point as possible. We then press 2ndCALC to see the Calculate menu. We press 5 for intersect, and respond to each of the calculatorâ€™s questions, First curve?, Second curve?, and Guess?, by pressing ENTER. The calculator then displays the intersection point, x = 4.36, y = -2.85.

subsection.p: We can substitute these values into the original system to check that they satisfy both equations. 3(\alert{4.36}) - 2.8(\alert{-2.85}) \amp = 21.06 \amp\amp \glert{\text{True}}2(\alert{4.36}) + 1.2(\alert{-2.85}) \amp = 5.3 \amp\amp \glert{\text{True}}

subsection.title: Inconsistent and Dependent Systems
subsection.p: Because two straight lines do not always intersect at a single point, a 2\times 2 system of linear equations does not always have a unique solution. In fact, there are three possibilities, as illustrated below.

definition.title: Solutions of Linear Systems
definition.p:
There are three types of 2 \times 2 linear systemslinear system:
Consistent and independent systemconsistentindependent. The graphs of the two lines intersect in exactly one point. The system has exactly one solution.
Inconsistent systeminconsistent. The graphs of the equations are parallel lines and hence do not intersect. An inconsistent system has no solutions.
Dependent systemdependent. All the solutions of one equation are also solutions to the second equation, and hence are solutions of the system. The graphs of the two equations are the same line. A dependent system has infinitely many solutions.

li.p: We use the calculator to graph both equations on the same axes. First, we rewrite the second equation in slope-intercept form by solving for y. 2x + 2y \amp = 3\amp\amp \glert{\text{Substract } 2x \text{ from both sides.}}2y \amp = -2x + 3\amp\amp \glert{\text{Divide both sides by 2.}}y \amp = -x + 1.5 We enter the equations as Y_1 \amp= -X + 5Y_2 \amp = -X + 1.5 You should see that the lines do not intersect within the viewing window; they appear to be parallel. If we look again at the equations of the lines, we recognize that both have slope -1 but different y-intercepts, so they are parallel. Because parallel lines never meet, there is no solution to the system.
This time we will graph by hand. We begin by writing each equation in slope-intercept form.

The two equations are actually different forms of the same equation. They are equivalent, so they share the same line as a graph. Every point on the first line is also a point on the second line, and hence a solution of the system. The system has infinitely many solutions.

subsection.title: Applications
subsection.p: Systems of equations are useful in many applied problems. One example involves supply and demand. The owner of a retail business must try to balance the demand for his product from consumers with the supply he can obtain from manufacturers. Supply and demand both vary with the price of the product: consumers usually buy fewer items if the price increases, but manufacturers will be willing to supply more units of the product if its price increases.

The demand equationdemand equation gives the number of units of the product that consumers will buy at a given price. The supply equationsupply equation gives the number of units that theproducer will supply at that price. The price at which the supply and demand are equal is called the equilibrium priceequilibrium price. This is the price at which the consumer and the producer agree to do business

statement.p: A woolens mill can produce 400x yards of fine suit fabric if it can charge x dollars per yard. The mill's clients in the garment industry will buy 6000 - 100x yards of wool fabric at a price of x dollars per yard. Find the equilibrium price and the amount of fabric that will change hands at that price.

li.p: We choose variables for the unknown quantities.

li.title: Step 2
li.p: The supply equation tells us how many yards of fabric the mill will produce for a price of x dollars per yard. y=400x The demand equation tells us how many yards of fabric the garment industry will buy at a price of x dollars per yard. y = 6000 - 100x

li.title: Step 3
li.p: We graph the two equations on the same set of axes, as shown below. We set the window values to \text{Xmin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Xmax} = 94\text{Ymin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Ymax} = 6200 and use the TRACE or the intersect command to locate the solution. The graphs intersect at the point (12, 4800).

image.description: GC graph of supply and demand of wool fabric

li.title: Step 4
li.p: The equilibrium price is $12 per yard, and the mill will sell 4800 yards of fabric at that price.

subsection.title: Substitution Method
subsection.p: You are probably familiar with the substitution method for solving a system of equations. Here is a summary of the steps for solving a system by substitution.

assemblage.title: To Solve a System by Substitution

li.p: Choose one of the variables in one of the equations. (It is best to choose a variable whose coefficient is 1 or -1.) Solve the equation for that variable.
Substitute the result of Step 1 into the other equation. This gives an equation in one variable.
Solve the equation obtained in Step 2. This gives the solution value for one of the variables.
Substitute this value into the result of Step 1 to find the solution value of the other variable.

statement.p: Staci stocks two kinds of sleeping bags in her sporting goods store, a standard model and a down-filled model for colder temperatures. From past experience, she estimates that she will sell twice as many of the standard variety as of the down-filled. She has room to stock 84 sleeping bags at a time. How many of each variety should Staci order?

solution.p: We begin by choosing variables for the unknown quantities. \amp\text{Number of standard sleeping bags: }~x\amp\text{Number of down-filled sleeping bags: }~y

We write two equations about the variables. \amp\text{Staci needs twice as many standard model as down-filled: } \amp x \amp = 2y\amp\text{The total number of sleeping bags is 84: }\amp x+y \amp = 84 We will solve this system using substitution. Notice that the first equation is already solved for x in terms of y. We substitute \alert{2y} for x in the second equation to obtain \alert{2y} + y \amp = 843y\amp = 84 Solving for y, we find y=\alert{28}. Finally, substitute this value into the first equation to find x = 2(\alert{28}) = 56 The solution to the system is x = 56, y = 28. Staci should order 56 standard sleeping bags and 28 down-filled bags.

subsection.title: Elimination Method
subsection.p: A second algebraic method for solving systems is called elimination. As with the substitution method, we obtain an equation in a single variable, but we do it by eliminating one of the variables in the system. We must first put both equations into the general linear form Ax + By = C.

statement.p:
Solve the system
\begin{aligned}[t] 5x \amp = 2y+21\\ 2y \amp = 19-3x \end{aligned}

subsection.p:
In the previous Example, the elimination method worked because the coefficients of y in the two equations were opposites, 2 and -2. This caused the y-terms to cancel out when we added the two equations together. What if the coefficients of neither x nor y are opposites? Then we must multiply one or both of the equations in thes ystem by a suitable constant. Consider the system
4x+3y\amp = 7
3x+y\amp =-1
We can eliminate the y-terms if we multiply each term of the second equation by \alert{-3}, so that the coefficients of y will be opposites:
\alert{-3}(3x+y=-1) ~ \longrightarrow ~ {-9x}-3y=3
Be careful to multiply each term by -3, not just the y-term. We can now replace the second equation by its new version to obtain this system:
4x+3y\amp = 7
-9x-3y\amp =3

subsection.p: When we add a multiple of one equation to the other we are making a linear combinationlinear combination of the equations. The method of elimination is also called the method of linear combinations. Sometimes we need to multiply both equations by suitable constants in order to eliminate one of the variables.

statement.p: Use linear combinations to solve the system 5x-2y \amp = 222x - 5y \amp =13

solution.p: This time we choose to eliminate the x-terms. We must arrange things so that the coefficients of the x-terms are opposites, so we look for the smallest integer that both 2 and 5 divide into evenly. (This number is called the lowestâ€¯commonâ€¯multiple, or LCM, of 2 and 5.) The LCM of 2 and 5 is 10. We want one of the coefficients of x to be 10, and the other to be -10.

To achieve this, we multiply the first equation by 2 and the second equation by -5.
\alert{2}(5x-2y\amp=22)\amp\amp \rightarrow\amp 10x - 4y \amp=44
\alert{-5}(2x-5y\amp=13)\amp\amp \rightarrow\amp -10x +25y \amp=-65
Adding these new equations eliminates the x-term and yields an equation in y.
10x - 4y \amp = \hphantom{-}44
\underline{-10x + 25y} \amp =\underline{ -65 \vphantom{y}}
21y \amp = -21
We solve for y to find y = -1. Finally, we substitute y = \alert{-1} into the first equation and solve for x.
5x-2(\alert{-1})\amp = 22
5x\amp = 20
x\amp = 4
The solution of the system is the point (4, -1).

Step 2
Eliminate the y-terms: Multiply each equation by an appropriate constant.
Step 3
Add the new equations and solve the result for x\text{.}
Step 4
Substitute your value for x into the second equation and solve for y\text{.}
The solution to the system is (Give the solution as an ordered pair.)

subsection.p: Which method should you choose to solve a particular system? Both methods work on any linear system, but the substitution method is easier if one of the variables in one of the equations has coefficient 1 or -1.

subsection.title: Inconsistent and Dependent Systems
subsection.p: Recall that a system of two linear equations does not always have a unique solution; it may be inconsistent or dependent. The elimination method will reveal whether the system falls into one of these two cases.

sidebyside.p: To eliminate the y-terms, we multiply the first equation by 2 and add: 6x-2y\amp =\hphantom{1}8\underline{-6x+2y}\amp = \underline{\hphantom{1}2\vphantom{y}} 0x+0y\amp =10

li.p: Both variables are eliminated, and we are left with the false statement 0 = 10. There are no values of x or y that will make this equation true, so thes system has no solutions. The graph shows that the system is inconsistent.

sidebyside.p: To eliminate the x-terms, we multiply the first equation by -2 and add: -2x+4y\amp =-6\underline{\hphantom{-}2x-4y}\amp = \underline{\hphantom{-}6\vphantom{y}} 0x+0y\amp =\hphantom{-}0

li.p: We are left with the true but unhelpful equation 0 = 0. The two equations are in fact equivalent (one is a constant multiple of the other), so the system is dependent. The graph of both equations is shown in the figure.

assemblage.title: Inconsistent and Dependent Systems
assemblage.p:
When using elimination to solve a system:
If combining the two equations results in an equation of the form
0x+0y = k \amp\amp(k\ne 0)
then the system is inconsistent.
If combining the two equations results in an equation of the form
0x+0y =0
then the system is dependent.

statement.p: Identify the system as dependent, inconsistent, or consistent and independent x+3y=6-12=-6y 2x-12=-6y

solution.p: Dependent

statement.p: Identify the system as dependent, inconsistent, or consistent and independent

li.p: dependent
inconsistent
consistent and independent

statement.p:
Solve the system by substitution:
\begin{aligned}[t] 2x \amp = y+7\\ 2y \amp = 14-3x \end{aligned}
Step 1
Choose one of the equations, and solve for one of the variables.
Step 2
Substitute this new expression for x or y into the other equation.
Step 3
Notice that the new equation has only one variable. Solve the equation.
Step 4
Substitute the answer to Step 3 into the result of Step 1 to find the other variable. Write your solution as an ordered pair.

Solve the system by elimination:
\begin{aligned}[t] 3x+5y \amp = 1\\ 2x-3y \amp = 7 \end{aligned}
Step 1
We choose to eliminate x. Multiply the first equation by 2 and the second equation by -3. (Why?) \alert{2}[3x+5y=1] \amp\rightarrow \hphantom{other side of equation} \alert{-3}[2x-3y=7] \amp\rightarrow \hphantom{other side of equation}
Step 2
The coefficients of x are now opposites. Add the two equations together.
Step 3
Solve the new equation for the remaining variable.
Step 4
Use substitution to find the other variable. Write your solution as an ordered pair.

introduction.p: For Problems 3 and 4, clear the fractions in each equation first, then solve the sys-tem by substitution or by linear combinations.
For Problems 5 and 6, use linear combinations to identify each system as dependent, inconsistent, or consistent and independent.

Geologists can calculate the distance from their seismograph to the epicenter of an earthquake by timing the arrival of the P and S waves. They know that, for this earthquake, P waves travel at about 5.4 miles per second and S waves travel at 3.0 miles per second. If the P waves arrived 3 minutes before the S waves, how far away is the epicenter of the quake?

subsection.title: 3\times 3 Linear Systems
subsection.p:
A solutionsolution to an equation in three variables, such as x + 2y - 3z = -4 is an ordered tripleordered triple of numbers that satisfies the equation. For example, (0, -2, 0) and (-1, 0, 1) are solutions to the equation above, but (1, 1, 1) is not. You can verify this by substituting the coordinates into the equation to see if a true statement results.
\amp\text{For }(0,-2, 0):{}\amp \alert{0} {}+{}\amp 2(\alert{-2}) \amp{}-{}\amp 3(\alert{0}) \amp = -4{}\amp\hphantom{blank} \glert{\text{True}}\amp
\amp\text{For }(-1, 0, 1):{}\amp \alert{-1} {}+{}\amp 2(\alert{0}) \amp{}-{}\amp 3(\alert{1}) \amp = -4{}\amp\hphantom{blank} \glert{\text{True}}\amp
\amp\text{For }(1, 1, 1):{}\amp \alert{1} {}+{}\amp 2(\alert{1}) \amp{}-{}\amp 3(\alert{1}) \amp = -4{}\amp\hphantom{blank} \glert{\text{Not true}}\amp
A linear equation in three variables has infinitely many solutions.

sidebyside.p: An ordered triple (x, y, z) can be represented geometrically as a point in space using a three-dimensional Cartesian coordinate system,as shown in the figure. The graph of a linear equation in three variables is a plane.

subsection.p: A solution to a system of three linear equations in three variables is an ordered triple that satisfies each equation in the system. That triple represents a point where all three planes intersect. If the planes intersect in a single point, the system has a unique solution. If there is no point that lies on all three planes (for instance, if at least two of the planes are parallel), the system is inconsistent. If all three planes are the same, or if they intersect in a line, the system is dependent.

It is impractical to solve 3\times 3 systems by graphing. Even when technology for producing three-dimensional graphs is available, we cannot read coordinates on such graphs with any confidence. Thus, we will restrict our attention to algebraic methods of solving such systems.

subsection.title: Back-Substitution
subsection.p: The strategy for solving a 3 \times 3 system is the same as the strategy for 2 \times 2 systems: we would like to reduce the system to an equation in a single variable. Once we have found the value for that variable, we substitute its value into the other equations to find the remaining unknowns.

A special case of this technique is called back-substitutionback-substitution. It works when one of the equations involves exactly one variable, and a second equation involves that same variable and just one other variable. A 3 \times 3 system with these properties is said to be in triangular formtriangular form.

statement.p: Solve the system x +{} 2y \amp {}+{} \amp 3z \amp {}={} \amp 2 -2y \amp {}-{} \amp 4z \amp {}={} \amp -2 \amp {}{} \amp 3z \amp {}={} \amp -3

solution.p: We begin by solving the third equation to find z = -1. Then we substitute \alert{-1} for z in the second equation and solve for y. -2y - 4(\alert{-1}) \amp = -2-2y + 4 \amp= -2-2y \amp = -6y\amp=3 Finally, we substitute \alert{-1} for z and \alert{3} for y into the first equation to find x. x + 2(\alert{3}) + 3(\alert{-1}) \amp= 2x + 6 - 3 \amp = 2x\amp=-1 The solution is the ordered triple (-1, 3, -1). You should verify that this triple satisfies all three equations of the system.

statement.p: Use back-substitution to solve the system 2x +{}2y \amp {}+{} \amp z \amp {}={} \amp 10y \amp {}-{} \amp 4z \amp {}={} \amp 9\amp {}{} \amp 3z \amp {}={} \amp -6

instructions.p: Give the solution as an ordered triple.

statement.p: Use back-substitution to solve the system
Give the solution as an ordered triple.

subsection.title: Gaussian Reduction
subsection.p: The method for solving a general 3 \times 3 linear system is called Gaussian reductionGaussian reduction, after the German mathematician Carl Gauss. We use linear combinations to reduce the system to triangular form, and then use back-substitution to find the solutions.

subsection.p: To obtain the triangular form, we eliminate one of the variables from each of thethree equations by considering them in pairs. This results in a 2\times 2 system that we can solve using elimination.

statement.p: Solve the system: x \amp {}+{} \amp 2y \amp {}-{} \amp 3z \amp {}={} \amp -4\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (1)2x \amp {}-{} \amp y \amp {}+{} \amp z \amp {}={} \amp 3\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (2)3x \amp {}+{} \amp 2y \amp {}+{} \amp z \amp {}={} \amp 10\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (3)

solution.p: We can choose any one of the three variables to eliminate first. For this example, we will eliminate x. Next, we choose two of the equations, say (1) and (2), and use a linear combination: We multiply Equation (1) by -2 and add the result to Equation (2) to produce Equation (4). -2x \amp {}-{} \amp 4y \amp {}+{} \amp 6z \amp {}={} \amp 8\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (1\text{a})\underline{\hphantom{-}2x\vphantom{y}} \amp \underline{{}-{}\vphantom{y}} \amp \underline{\hphantom{-5}y} \amp \underline{{}+{}\vphantom{y} }\amp \underline{\hphantom{6}z\vphantom{y}} \amp {}={} \amp \underline{\hphantom{1}\vphantom{y} 3}\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (2) \amp \amp{-5y} \amp {}+{} \amp 7z \amp {}={} \amp 11\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (4)

Now we have an equation involving only two variables. But we need two equations in two unknowns to find the solution. So we choose a different pair of equations, say (1) and (3), and eliminate x again. We multiply Equation (1) by -3 and add the result to Equation (3) to obtain Equation (5). -3x \amp {}-{} \amp 6y \amp {}+{} \amp 9z \amp {}={} \amp 12\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (1\text{b})\underline{\hphantom{-}3x\vphantom{y}} \amp \underline{{}+{}\vphantom{y}} \amp \underline{\hphantom{-}2y} \amp \underline{{}+{}\vphantom{y} }\amp \underline{\hphantom{10}z\vphantom{y}} \amp {}={} \amp \underline{\vphantom{y}10}\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (3) \amp \amp{-4y} \amp {}+{} \amp 10z \amp {}={} \amp 22\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (5)
We now form a 2\times 2 system with our new Equations (4) and (5). -5y\amp + \amp 7z \amp = 11 \hphantom{blankblank} (4)-4y\amp + \amp 10z \amp = 22 \hphantom{blankblank} (5)

Finally, we eliminate one of the remaining variables to obtain an equation in a single variable. We choose to eliminate y, so we add 4 times Equation (4) to -5 times Equation (5) to obtain Equation (6). -20y~\amp {}+{} \amp 28z \amp =\hphantom{-1} 44 \hphantom{blankblank} (4\text{a})\underline{\hphantom{-}20y~}\amp\underline{{}-{}\vphantom{{}+ y~}} \amp \underline{\hphantom{-}50z\vphantom{ -20y~}} \amp = \underline{-110\vphantom{y}} \hphantom{blankblank} (5\text{a})\amp \amp -22z \amp = \hphantom{1}{-66} \hphantom{blankblankl} (6)

Now we are ready to form a triangular system. We choose one of the original equations (in three variables), one of the equations from our 2\times 2 system, and our final equation in one variable. We choose Equations (1), (4), and (6). x \amp {}+{} \amp 2y \amp {}-{} \amp 3z \amp {}={} \amp -4\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (1) \amp {}{} \amp -5 y \amp {}+{} \amp 7z \amp {}={} \amp 11\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (4) \amp \amp \amp {}{} \amp -22z \amp {}={} \amp -66\amp\hphantom{blankblank} (6)

This new system has the same solutions as the original system, and we can solveit by back-substitution. We first solve Equation (6) to find z = 3. Substituting 3 for z in Equation (4), we find -5y+7(\alert{3}) \amp=11 -5y+21 \amp=11 -5y \amp=-10
So y = 2. Finally, we substitute \alert{3} for z and \alert{2} for y into Equation (1) to find x+2(\alert{2})-3(\alert{3}) \amp= -4 x+4-9 \amp= -4 x \amp= 1
The solution to the system is the ordered triple (1, 2, 3). You should verify that this triple satisfies all three of the original equations.

subsection.p: We summarize the method for solving a 3\times 3 linear system as follows.

assemblage.title: Steps for Solving a 3\times 3 Linear System

li.p: Clear each equation of fractions and put it in standard form.
Choose two of the equations and eliminate one of the variables by forming a linear combination.
Choose a different pair of equations and eliminate the same variable.
Form a 2\times 2 system with the equations found in steps (2) and (3). Eliminate one of the variables from this 2\times 2 system by using a linear combination.
Form a triangular system by choosing among the previous equations. Use back-substitution to solve the triangular system.

authored.pg-code: $elsm = RadioButtons( ["Form a triangular system.", "Eliminate either \(x\) or \(z\).", "Eliminate \(y\) again from a different pair of equations.", "Substitute the value for \(y\) into the equations."], 2, );

statement.p: Suppose you eliminate y from two equations as Step 2 of Gaussian elimina-tion. What should you do for Step 3?

solution.p: Eliminate y again from a different pair of equations.

statement.p: Suppose you eliminate y from two equations as Step 2 of Gaussian elimina-tion. What should you do for Step 3?

li.p: Form a triangular system.
Eliminate either x or z.
Eliminate y again from a different pair of equations.
Substitute the value for y into the equations.

solution.p: Eliminate y again from a different pair of equations.

Step 1: Clear the fractions from Equation (2).
Step 2: Eliminate z from Equations (1) and (2).
Step 3: Eliminate z from Equations (1) and (3).
Step 4: Eliminate x from your new 2\times 2 system.
Step 5: Form a triangular system and solve by back-substitution.

subsection.title: Inconsistent and Dependent Systems
subsection.p: If, at any step in forming linear combinations, we obtain an equation of the form 0x + 0y + 0z = k, \qquad (k \ne 0) then the system is inconsistent and has no solution. If we donâ€™t obtain such an equation, but we do obtain one of the form 0x + 0y + 0z = 0 then the system is dependent and has infinitely many solutions.

li.p: To eliminate y from Equations (1) and (2), we multiply Equation (1) by -2 and add the result to Equation (2). -6x \amp {}-{} \amp 2y \amp {}+{} \amp 4z \amp {}={} \amp -2\underline{\hphantom{-}6x\vphantom{y}} \amp \underline{{}+{}\vphantom{y}} \amp \underline{2y} \amp \underline{{}-{}\vphantom{y} }\amp \underline{4z\vphantom{y}} \amp {}={} \amp \underline{\hphantom{-}5} 0x\amp {}+{}\amp{0y} \amp {}+{} \amp 0z \amp {}={} \amp 3~ Because the resulting equation has no solution, the system is inconsistent.

To eliminate x from Equations (1) and (3), we multiply Equation (1) by 2 and add Equation (3). -2x \amp {}+{} \amp 6y \amp {}-{} \amp 2z \amp {}={} \amp -4\underline{\hphantom{-}2x\vphantom{y}} \amp \underline{{}-{}\vphantom{y}} \amp \underline{6y} \amp \underline{{}+{}\vphantom{y} }\amp \underline{2z\vphantom{y}} \amp {}={} \amp \underline{\hphantom{-}4} 0x\amp {}+{}\amp{0y} \amp {}+{} \amp 0z \amp {}={} \amp 0~ Because the resulting equation vanishes, the system is dependent and has infinitely many solutions.
